column8: description

Site of the family home and surgery of Harold Moody, which also served as the headquarters of the League of Colored Peoples (LCP) until 1937. Harold Moody arrived in Britain from Jamaica in 1904 and, after training as a doctor at King's College, his house in Peckham became a central meeting point for a huge number of Caribbean and African political activists.

Site of the Camberwell Green Congregational Church, where prominent activist Harold Moody was a lay preacher and deacon. Moody, whose home and surgery was a short distance away, promoted racial justice to his congregation and his funeral was held here upon his death in 1947.

Site where prominent activist Harold Moody met the Queen at Buckingham Palace at an event marking the purchase of mobile canteens by colonial governments to help people during the Blitz. The Palace was also the site where Trinidadian cricketer Learie Constantine was knighted in May 1947 and Nigerian lawyer Adeyemo Alakija was knighted in 1945.

Site where a V2 rocket landed on a busy Woolworth's store in 1944, killing around 200 people. Local doctor and politcal activist Harold Moody, orginally from Jamaica, was one of the first on scene tending to victims.

Site of a nightclub set up by Sierra Leoneon Ernest Marke which was especially popular with African American GIs after their arrival in the country. It also hosted political discussions by anti-colonial protestors including African nationalists like Jomo Kenyatta and Kwame Nkrumah.
Site of a nightclub owned by Sierra Leoneon Ernest Marke.

Site of the Imperial Hotel where famous Trinidadian cricketer Learie Constantine and his family were refused admittance in 1943, with the manager blaming 'the Americans'. Constantine subsequently took the hotel to court and won his case in a landmark ruling.

Site of the offices of the Universal Negro Improvement Association (UNIA), Jamaican Marcus Garvey's famous interwar nationalist organization, that he attempted to revive from London in the late 1930s.
Site of the home of Marcus Garvey, a famous Jamaican pioneer of black nationalism in the interwar period who spent the final years of his life in London.
Site of the home of Esther Bruce, a hospital cleaner and fire watcher whose father had settled in London from British Guiana early in the twentieth century.

Site of the hospital where Esther Bruce, whose father had settled in London from British Guiana early in the twentieth century, was a wartime cleaner. She worked on a ward for injured service personnel and acted as a fire watcher.
Site of the home of Joseph Cozier from British Guiana and Florence Tindling who sent three children to be evacuated to Great Bedwin, Wilts.
Site of the school from where Christopher, Joseph and Joan Cozier (children of Joseph Cozier from British Guiana) were evacuated to Great Bedwin near Marlborough in Wiltshire.

Site of the street where Kenny Lynch, son of Oscar Lynch from Barbados and mother Amelia, remembers being bombed out of three houses during the Blitz. Kenny Lynch later had a successful musical career after the war.

Site of the Houses of Parliament, visited by Jamaican technicians working in Liverpool whose visit to the capital was sponsored by the League of Coloured Peoples. In addition, Guyanese clarinetist and bandleader Rudolph Dunbar reported on debates over the Italian invasion of Ethiopia in 1935 and weekly West African Parliamentary Committee meetings took place from 1942.
Site of the Tower of London, visited by Jamaican technicians working in Liverpool whose visit to the capital in 1942 was sponsored by the League of Coloured Peoples.
Site of St. Paul's Cathedral, visited by Jamaican technicians working in Liverpool whose visit to the capital in 1942 sponsored by the League of Coloured Peoples.

Site of Madame Tussauds, visited by Jamaican technicians working in Liverpool whose visit to the capital in 1942 was sponsored by the League of Coloured Peoples. It was also visited by African American soldiers of the 643rd Port Company during leave.
Site of the cinema where black Londoner Len Bradbook worked. Bradbook lived nearby and was also involved in civilian defence.

Site of the New Florida Nightclub, co-owned by American jazz singer Adelaide Hall and Trinidadian entrepreneur Bertram Hicks. This was a private members club popular with service personnel which was visited by Bob Hope and Fred Astaire and was bombed in October 1940.
Site of the Lewisham Hippodrome where American jazz singer Adelaide Hall performed to a crowd in the midst of an air raid in the summer of 1940.
Site of The Prince of Wales Theatre, where Jamaican musician Leslie Hutchinson appeared in a production of 'Happidrome', a popular BBC radio series of the time.

Site of the Royal Albert Hall, where many black performers including Jamican Leslie 'Hutch' Hutchinson and American Paul Robeson appeared. The Hall held fundraising galas including the 1943 event 'Seventy Years of Song', where 'Hutch' performed in aid of 'Toc H' and hosted a giant rally for Republic Spain in June 1937. Guyanese clarinetist and bandleader Rudolph Dunbar conducted the London Philharmonic here in 1942, attracting an audience of 7,000. In 1945 the World Youth Conference took place here, with many delegates coming from Asia, Africa and the Caribbean.

Site of the Piccadilly Theatre, where American singer, actress and entertainer Elisabeth Welch joined an all-star cast at benefit concert for London fire service orphans. Others on the line up included Noel Coward and John Gielgud.
Site of the Stage Door Canteen, opened by Bing Crosby in 1944 and very popular with US service personnel. American singer, actress and entertainer Elisabeth Welch was a regular performer.
Site of the Old Florida Club where jazz band leader and dancer Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson and his band had a residency between 1936-1938. It was completely destroyed by a German bomb in 1940.
Site of Willerby's Club where jazz band leader and dancer Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson and his band had a residency in 1939

Site of the Cafe de Paris where jazz band leader and dancer Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson his band - widely regarded as the best in London - played during the Blitz.  However, a German bomb landed on the building in March 1941, killing Ken and several others in the band. The underground venue had previously been 'advertised as London's safest restaurant'.

Site of Aggrey House, a hostel set up by the Colonial Office and used by people from across west Africa and the Caribbean and some from south and east Africa. Leaders of the West African Students Union (WASU) were fiercely critical of the initiative which they saw as another instance of the British government's attempt to control colonial subjects. Nonetheless, it became a popular destination for black visitors to the capital in the late 1930s and early 1940s.

Site of the Colonial Centre, the successor to Aggrey House (another hostel set up by the Colonial Office and used by people from across west Africa and the Caribbean) established by the government in wartime as a home for 'colonial' students.

Site of 'Africa House', a hostel for African students and the headquarters of the the West African Students Union (WASU). Africa House was a hub of black activity in London, especially for Nigerian students, and talks and dances that were both social and political occasions were held here regularly.
Site of the hospital where Marcus Garvey Jr., son of famous black nationalist Marcus Garvey, was taken sick in spring 1938 before returning to Jamaica soon after.

Site of the docks connecting UK with Caribean, used by Jamaican activist Amy Jacques Garvey (the second wife of famous pan-African nationalist Marcus Garvey) and her family to return home to the Caribbean in 1938 after their stay in the city.

column3: University of London, Institute of Education,
column8: Site of the Ministry of Information, which employed Trinidadian radicial writer George Padmore and Nigerian pianist Fela Sowande during the war. It was also home to the Institute of Education, which ran a service to train 'colonial' teachers.

Site of various political rallies: in 1935 for protest against Italian aggression in Ethiopia, in 1936 for a Pan African Federation rally against colonialism in 1936, in 1937 and 1938 for groups acting in soldiarity with West Indian Workers, and in 1947 for demonstrations against the Richards Constitution introduced in Nigeria. During a U.S. military parade here in 1943, the black soldiers were given the loudest cheer.

Site of the Florence Mills Social Parlour, set up by activist Amy Ashwood Garvey and her Trinidadian partner Sam Manning, which later became the Blue Lagoon Club, a jazz club and site for black intellectuals to meet.
Site of the house where Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie briefly stayed in summer 1936

Site of the flat where Trinidadian writer and radical activist George Padmore lived and hosted visitors. The flat bustled with a constant stream of activity and served as a focal point for activists from around the world. It was described by historian Winston James as 'the workshop of the African anti-colonial struggle.'

Site of the headquarters of the BBC, where black figures gave talks and performed on several occasions, notably in the radio series 'Caribbean Voices' and 'Calling the West Indies'. Jamaican writer, poet and journalist Una Marson was a regular contributor, while Trinidadian cricketer Learie Constantine frequently appeared on the 'Brains Trust' programme from 1943 onwards. BBC programs were highly respected and listened to by a wide cross-section of the public.

Site of an entertainment venue in North London where black artists performed, Jamaican writer Una Marson learnt to produce programmes, and where African-American duo 'Buck and Bubbles' appeared on the first regular BBC broadcast in 1936. In 1939, Alexandra Palace was described as 'a site of unpredictable chaos with cables inside all over the floor, some of them as big as water hoses'.

Site of a jazz club that was noted as a 'haven for people of African descent in London'. A small but buzzing venue, Jig's was the centre for Trinidadian jazz and calypso musician Cyril Blake's band from where a live broacast was recorded in December 1941, presented by Harry Parry. English jazz singer Beryl Bryden described the club as being in 'the sort of area that didn't have a very savoury reputation in those days'. Inside it had 'about eighty percent coloured people - West Indians, mostly - and there in the corner is this wonderful little jazz band... The club was rather dark, and very smoke-filled; a real America-type club'. It closed following a police raid in 1942.
Site of a jazz club 'with a predominantly black audience' that was under Caribbean ownership. Newsreel footage from 1947 shows audience dancing to calypso and Harlem-style Jazz.

Site of a gallery which hosted the work of black sculptor Ronald Moody in spring 1946. The work, Levels of Organization, 'was an undisguised critique of Western scientific advance, inspired by the immediate example of the war and its nuclear resolution'.

Site of a gallery which hosted the work of black sculptor Ronald Moody in early 1935. Moody's work, Head with Superimposed Mask, was described by the curators as an example of 'contemporary Negro' work.
Site of the Charing Cross Hotel, where Barbadian and future actor Earl Cameron worked washing dishes in 1940.

Site of the Savoy Hotel, where Barbadian and future actor Earl Cameron worked as a diswasher in 1942 and Trinidadian cricketer Learie Constantine attended a Knights of the Round Table dinner in April 1945.

Site of the the Palace Theatre, where Barbadian Earl Cameron got his first acting role in a performance of 'Chu Chin Chow'. Cameron got the role after his friend recommended him following another player falling ill.
Site of the Royal Academy of Music, which trained black artists, including Trinidadian pianist Winifred Atwell.

Site of the 20th Century Theatre, where the first season of 'Les Ballets Negres' was presented in spring 1946. Les Ballets Negres 'laid the foundation for Caribean and African theatrical dance in Britain'.
Site of the Camberwell School of Art, which trained black artists including Guyanese Denis Williams.
Site of a munitions factory that briefly employed Caribbean calyso singer Edric Connor.

Site of the LSE, a prestigious university in London where numerous black figures studied, including Jomo Kenyatta, Nathanial Fadipe and Eslanda Robeson. LSE allowed Kenyatta's admission as part of an effort to educate 'colonial' students. St Lucian economist Arthur Lewis was appointed the first black lecturer here in 1938, following the completion of his PhD. Lewis would go on to become the first black professor in the UK following a move to Manchester in 1948.

Site of a Limehouse Pub called Charlie Brown's that was popular with sailors from across the world. Black patrons featured in the 1945 newsreel 'Peace on Earth' that celebrated the end of the war in the Pacific in an unusual public acknowledgement of interracial socializing.
Site of celebrations to mark the ending of the war in the Pacific, which included black people such as famous racing tipster Ras Prince Monolulu (Peter McKay).

Site of the hotel where Trinidadian cricketer Learie Constantine and family were relocated following being barred from the nearby Imperial. The Bedford was owned by the same company as the Imperial, with staff choosing the replacement after supposedly being 'moved' by Constantine's 'assertion of Britishness'.
Site of the hospital where Omo-Oba Adenrule Ademola, daughter of a paramount chief in Nigeria, worked in the late 1930s and 1940s.
Site of the Privy Council Chambers, where judiciaries reviewed legal appeals, including the 1937 appeal of Sierra Leoneon activist I.T.A. Wallace-Johnson against his charges of sedition.

Site of an open debating platform in Hyde Park, where black activists of the International African Friends of Ethiopia (IAFE) and the International Africa Service Bureau (IASB) spoke often in the second half of the 1930s. Audiences in 1937 were particularly interested in Ethiopia and the West Indian strikes and famous Jamaican pan-African figurehead Marcus Garvey also appeared before his death in 1940.
Site of the Hammersmith Palais where Frank Holder from British Guiana performed in the middle years of the 1940s.
Site of the Lyceum Ballroom where Frank Holder from British Guiana performed in the middle years of the 1940s.
Site of the 400 club in Leicester Square, a place American singer Elisabeth Welch described as 'very chic', where black Londoner Reginald Forsyth performed several times a week  in the 1930s.
Site of the Air Ministry building where Bill Strachan from Jamaica defied protocal and applied directly to join the RAF in 1940

Site of Piccadilly Circus, where crowds gathered at the end of the war, including Trinidadian RAF pilot Ulric Cross and 'Ambrose' Campbell's band the West African Rhythm Brothers. Campbell recalled 'People didn't know what was going on, but they joined in'.
Site of the house where Trinidadian activist and Marxist C.L.R. James lived in the mid 1930s.

Site of the one bedroom flat where the first president of Ghana, Kwame Nkrumah, lived between 1945 and 1947 and hosted political meetings and racially mixed parties. Nkrumah was mentored by Trinidadian activist George Padmore, who knew him through Trinidian Marxist writer C.L.R. James.
Site of the house where the future president of Botswana, Seretse Khama, lived between 1946 and 1948.

Site of the headquarters of the the West African Students Union (WASU) from June 1938 onwards. It was a centre of social life and political discussion especially popular with Nigerian students and had 12 beds, a library and cafe.
Site of the residence of Kenyan nationalist Jomo Kenyatta in the mid-1930s, where Trinidadian activist George Padmore also stayed.
Site of the temporary residence of Trinidadian activist George Padmore.
Site of the residence of Trinidadian student, historian and future Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago Eric Williams and wife Elsie.
Site of the residence of Nana Joseph Emmanuel Appiah and other radicals from African west coast known as the 'Primrose gang' in mid 1940s.
Site of the residence of Barbadian communist Peter Blackman. Blackman was a poet and associate of African American political luminaries Paul Robeson and W.E.B. Du Bois.

Site of the residence of South African novelist Peter Abrahams. Abrahams was an associate of various anti-colonial activists including Trinidadian George Padmore and African nationalists Jomo Kenyatta and Kwame Nkrumah.
Site of the residence of Ghanaian intelletual K. A. B. Jones-Quartney.
Site of the residence of Nigerian musician Billy Olu Sholanke, associate of Ghanaian activist Kwame Nkrumah.

column2: Flat in St Pancras of Nigerian musician Oladipupo 'Ambrose' Campbell
column8: Site of the flat in St Pancras of Nigerian musician Oladipupo 'Ambrose' Campbell, the leader of the popular band the 'West African Rhythm Brothers'.

column2: Camden Town flat of Brewster Hughes, bandmate of Oladipupo 'Ambrose' Campbell
column8: Site of the Camden Town flat of Brewster Hughes, bandmate of Nigerian musician Oladipupo 'Ambrose' Campbell who played together in the 'West Africa Rhythm Brothers'.
Site of Student Movement House, founded by the Student Christian Movement in 1917 which served as a residence for black students in the interwar period.
Site where Jamaican jazz musician Leslie Thompson and Trinidadian musician Carl Barriteau lived at different points during the late 1930s and early 1940s.
Site of the Soho jazz club where black musicians played including Ghanaian musician Cab Kaye (Augustus Kwamlah Quaye).

Site of a Soho jazz club where black musicians played including Ghanaian musician Cab Kaye (Augustus Kwamlah Quaye) and where 'reefer cigarettes' were smoked. The Nest was closed in 1939 after police discovered a ring of jewellery thieves operating out of it.
Site of a dance hall on Tottenham Court Road famous for interracial patronage, where Ghanaian musician Cab Kaye (Augustus Kwamlah Quaye) was credited with breaking the 'colour bar'.

Site of the residence of Kenyan student and future president of an independent Kenya, Jomo Kenyatta, between 1933 and 1937, during which time he appeared as an extra in the film 'Sanders of the River'.
Site of Ciro's Club, where gay African American performer Jimmie Daniels performed in the 1930s.

Site of the London theatre where the film 'Sanders of the River' debuted in April 1935, starring American actor and activist Paul Robeson. Robeson left the movie theater halfway through, disgusted by the colonialism shown in the film. He was coaxed back by his wife Eslanda, also in attendence.
Site of an experimental theatre where Paul Robeson titled in a production of 'Basalik' in April 1935. Basalik was about an 'independent-minded African chief' and ran for three days.

Site of the theatre where American actor and activist Paul Robeson performed the play 'Stevedore' in May 1935. Stevedore ran for two weeks in London, but was even more popular in theatres aimed at black communities in places like New York City and Chicago.
Site of the first home of the Robeson family during their stay in London. American actor and activist Paul Robeson lived here with his wife, Eslanda, and his son, Paul Jr.

Site of the Westimster Theatre, where American actor and activist Paul Robeson played the lead in Trinidadian Marxist C.L.R. James's play 'Toussaint L'ouveture' in March 1936. The two performances of James' play here were sponsored by the Stage Society.

Site of the Unity Theatre, a workers' theatre which American actor and activist Robeson helped found as a working-class cultural institution. Robeson played without a fee in 1937 and Guyanese actor Robert Adams performed in 1939. Adams joined the theatre's professional company in 1946.

Site of the Victoria Palace Theatre, where American actor and activist Paul Robeson sang a benefit concert for Republic Spain in April 1937. The concert was organized to raise aid for the 'women and children of Republican Spain'.
Site of the house next to Hampstead Heath, with wonderful views, where the Robeson family lived from 1938 to 1939.

column2: The Hounarable Society of the Outer Temple
column8: Site of one of the four law courts of England and Wales, where Caribeans and Africans could train to become lawyers.

Site of the headquarters of the (first) Pan African Federation, which was run from the basement. As Guyanese activist T. Ras. Makonnen remembered: 'There wasn't any clear membership. A lot of them came around simply because we provided a base and a talking point where the coffee pot was almost always on the stove'.

Site of the 'Home of Cricket', where many black players played, most notably during the 1939 West Indies tour. Lord's was also the site of a number of games between 'dominions' and English teams during the war.

Site of a famous cricket ground in London where many black players played, most notably during the 1939 West Indies tour. Famous Trinidadian cricketer Learie Constantine made his last test match appearance here, scoring 76 runs.

column2: The Honourable Society of the Middle Temple
column8: Site of one of the four law courts of England and Wales, where Caribeans and Africans could train to become lawyers. Famous Trinidadian cricketer and Ministry of Labour employee Learie Constantine studied here in the mid-1940s.

Site where the 'All Colonial People's Conference' organized by the Pan African Federation (PAF) and West African Students Union (WASU) took place in June 1945. Trinidadian activist George Padmore was vital in the organizing of the conference, in which many black, white and Asian luminaries spoke.

Site of a Negro Welfare Association conference on 'the situation of blacks in Britain' in October 1935, which addressed 'black unemployment' and 'the lack of student housing' in Britain alongside events in the Gold Coast and Nyasaland. The Hall also saw a series of protest meetings in the late 1930s, a communist confernence against imperialism in 1940 and a public rally in support of the Nigerian general strike, held in July 1945. The  Nigeria protest was described as 'one of the largest rallies of coloured peoples ever witnessed in the British capital'.

Site of the Congregational Memorial Hall, headquarters of the League of Coloured Peoples between 1937 and 1939. The hall also hosted a 'Conference on African Peoples, Democracy and World Peace' in July 1939 and the Second Subject People's Conference in October 1945.

Site of the International Afro Restaurant, opened beneath the residence of Jamaican activist Amy Ashwood Garvey in 1935, which was both the birthplace and informal headquarters of the International African Friends of Ethiopia (IAFE). CLR James described the restaurant as 'very important to me' as he found 'English food uneatable'.

Site of the Cuba Club, owned by Trinidadian George 'Happy' Blake, where several Jamaican jazz musicians played in the 1930s and 1940s. The famous jazz club 'Ronnie Scott's' was founded here subsequently after the war.

Site of the No.1 Rhythm Club, in which mostly white, mostly male, jazz fans could hear the latest trends from live performances, often involving black musicians. Jamaican Bertie King and Barbadian Dave Wilkins collaborated with white musicians at an appearance here in 1938.
Site of the Rendezvous des Artistes, a club owned by Trinidadian George 'Happy' Blake, where many black musicians played.
Site of the Barbarina, a club owned by Trinidadian George 'Happy' Blake during the war.
Site of the Havana Club, where Trinidadian musician Cyril Blake's band played during the war.

Site of the Chesterfield Club, where Trinidadian musician Cyril Blake's band played during the war. The Club was set up by Clementine Churchill, Winston's wife, for visiting American and Dominion servicemen.
Site of the Panama Club, 'a drinking club with a small dance floor', where Jamaican musician Cyril Blake's band played in 1946 and Jamaican jazz performer Coleridge Goode played in 1942.

Site of the West Hamstead flat where Jamaican writer and broadcaster Una Marson lived during her second spell in London, during which time she did several pieces of work for the BBC. Jamaican Jazz musician Coleridge Goode briefly lived with Marson in 1942.

Site where several 'African chiefs' attended the coronation of George VI in May 1937. The African chiefs attending the coronation supported a resolution protesting recent Italian atrocities in Addis Ababa. On another occasion, a Nigerian lawyer and co-founder of the Nigerian Progress Union (NPU) was pictured in an image entitled 'Two Lawyers' taken at the opening of the Michaelmas Law Sittings at the abbey.
Site of Barbadian doctor Cecil Belfield Clarke's medical practice. Clarke was a friend and confident of famous pan-African leader W.E.B. Du Bois.

Site where Jamaican jazz musician Coleridge Goode and his band played at the Rose Room following the end of the Second World War. The beautiful art deco ballroom was a marked change from the grimy Soho clubs the band had previously been perfoming.
Site of the home of Barbadian doctor Cecil Belfield Clarke and his partner Pat Walter which also hosted the League of Coloured Peoples' fifth annual garden party in 1936.
Site of a Soho club where Trinidadian musician Cyril Blake played.

column3: Rudolph Dunbar School of Clarinet Playing
column8: Site of a school founded by Guyanese musician Rudolph Dunbar in 1931.

Site of the Drury Lane theatre, where American singer Adelaide Hall appeared in 'The Sun Never Sets' in 1938. Hall decided to stay in London following the show's run and became a well-known fixture on the Soho entertainment scene.

Site of a West End theatre where the Cotton Club Revue appeared in 1937 and where American singer Elisabeth Welch starred in 'Happy and Glorious' in the mid-1940s. It was the Cotton Club Revue's first time touring outside of New York.

Site of the Ethiopian Legation, which was sold due to lack of funds. Exiled Emperor Haile Selassie spent time here upon arriving in London in 1936, working with a retinue of advisors to galavanize political support for the Ethiopian cause from European governments like Britain's.

column2: Anti Air War Memorial, Highbeam House
column8: Site of a memorial commissioned and erected by the suffragist Sylvia Pankhurst in 1935 as 'a protest against war in the air'. It was unveiled by R. P. Zaphiro, secretary of the Imperial Ethiopian Legation. The memorial was vandalised and stolen on its first night, and had to be replaced.
Site of a tea house where Guyanese activist Ras T. Makonnen and others went for tea following the 1935 rally for Ethiopia.

Site of the train station where Emperor Haile Selassie arrived from Plymouth in 1936. The Emperor and Princess Tsehai were greeted by a group of admirers, including two young girls bearing flowers, organized by the International African Friends of Ethiopia (IAFE). Selassie was reportedly very touched by the affectionate welcome he received.
Site of a museum housing historial treasures from around the world. Guyanese activist T. Ras. Makonnen came here in 1935-6 to discover all he could about Ethiopian history.

Site of the house on Shoe Lane next to the offices of 'The Sketch' newspaper that served as the headquarters of the International Africa Service Bureau (IASB). The building also housed a Ghanaian known as Bresiando who led an anti-colonialist business venture known as the  'Cocoa Collective'.
Site of the flat where Guyanese activist T. Ras Makonnen briefly moved following a stint living with Trinidadian activist George Padmore. Soon after moving here, Makonnen moved up to Manchester

Site for the October 1935 National Peace Council council conference attended by many black political activists. It was also the site of numerous political protests in the late 1930s at which the International African Service Bureau (IASB) sold copies of 'Life and Struggles of Negro Toilers'.
Site of the Japanese Embassy, where T. Ras Makonnen visited to ask for the aid of the Japanese navy in evacuating refugees from Ethiopia. Makonnen's request was denied.
Site of an upmarket officer's club where Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader Edmundo Ross played in 1938

Site of the Mayfair Hotel, where Nigeroian chief, the Alake of Abeokuta, held an 'at home' in July 1936 and where Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader Edmundo Ross' band played a cabaret act soon after the war began.
Site of the Jazz Jamboree of 1944, where the African American 'Spirits of Rhythm' played alongside American Glenn Miller.
Site of a small nightclub where Trinidadian musician Rupert Nurse played in fellow Trinidadian Fitzroy Coleman's band following his arrival in London in 1945.
Site of Essex Hall, which was the headquarters of the League Against Imperialism where childhood friends and Trinidadian activists C.L.R. James and George Padmore became reacquainted in 1936 or 1937.
Site of the Empress Stadium, which housed a large rally by the League of Nations Union's National Youth Executve. Barbadian Marxist Peter Blackman spoke to a crowd of 10,000 at the event.

Site of the temporary meeting place for activists associated with the International African Friends of Ethiopia (IAFE) who eventually formed the Pan African Federation, including Trinidadian activist George Padmore and Kenyan nationalist Jomo Kenyatta.

Site of the temporary meeting place for activists associated with the International African Friends of Ethiopia (IAFE) who eventually formed the Pan African Federation, including Trinidadian activist George Padmore and Kenyan nationalist Jomo Kenyatta.

Site of the headquarters of the Victoria League, a London-based charitable organization run by women in support of the empire, where Ghanaian Desmond Buckle was a regular visitor in 1940. Buckle was one of over 60 West African students who 'were regularly in touch with the Victoria League'.

Site of the headquarters of London County Council, where the World Trade Union Conference - attended by several black delegates - was held in February 1945. The unprecedented African involvement indicated the growing strength of African labor. The Chicago Defender declared that it might be 'the most significant conference in history for the colored peoples of the world; because colonial peoples would have a voice and a vote in international affairs for the first time'.

Site of the temporary headquarters of the International Africa Service Bureau (IASB) between 1937 and 1938. Sierra Leoneon activist I.T.A. Wallace-Johnson started sleeping here when his funds ran low in 1938.

Site of a former Independent Labour Party (ILP) building and Headquarters of the International Africa Service Bureau (IASB) after 1938, which was also home to Guyanese activist Ras T. Makonnnen and American William Harrison. Sierra Leoneon activist I.T.A Wallace-Johnsonâs departure left the bureau in disarray, and Trinidadian activist George Padmore had to scramble for money to rent a new office. He turned to the ILP for support, moving the IASBâs offices into this building.
Site of the offices of the League Against Imperialism (LAI). The LAI offices were a rendevous for black activists opposed to empire and galvanized by the Italian invasion of Ethiopia.

column2: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine
column8: Site of a London University school for studying tropical diseases which had some African and Caribbean students in the late 1930s and 40s. These included South African activist Alfred B Xuma and, during his spell at the school, Xuma met Trinidadian activist George Padmore and other members of the International Africa Service Bureau (IASB) who helped to influence his views concerning the situation in South Africa which was just a decade away from instituting full legal apartheid.

Site of the headquarters of the official Communist Party of Great Britain who attracted a small but significant number of black members during the 1930s. These included Ghanaian radical Desmond Buckle who was among the most committed and engaged black members of the party in Britain.
Site of Babalola Wilkie's club on Greek Street. Wilkie was a Nigerian involved in the IASB and his club had a multiracial roster of patrons and featured black musicians including Laurie Deniz played

column3: School of Oriental and African Studies
column8: Site of the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), which was attended by many black students. The School was evacuated to Christ College Cambridge in 1939.

column3: University of London, Institute of Education
column8: Site of the Institute of Education which ran a special training program for 'colonial' teachers. The School was moved to Senate House in 1938 and then evacuated to Nottingham in 1939.
Site of the headquarters of the Unilever Corporation, where Nigerian writer Nathaniel Fedipe worked as a clerk following the completion of his PhD.
Site of University College London some black students, including Guyanese historian Elsa Goveia, studied during the 1930s and 1940s.

Site of the Hans Crescent Hostel, regular meeting place of the West Indian Students' Union (WISU) following its establishment in 1945. The WISU 'included during its early years a number of future luminaries in the cultural, political and intellectual life of the Caribbean'.

Site of the National Gallery, where the wartime film 'Men of Two Worlds' was unable to shoot because Dame Myra Jess banned the lead black Guyanese actor, Robert Adams, from performing on account of his race. The opening scene of the film thus took place at a fake set of the National Gallery which had to be built from scratch. The film was eventually released in 1946.
Site of the Royal College of Organists, where Nigerian pianist Fela Sowande became a fellow in 1943. Sowande headed his class and garnered a litany of prizes and awards.
Site of the headquarters of the International African Service Bureau (IASB) after 1939 which was also the offices of the Independent Labour Party.
Site of the headquarters of the Colonial Office, where activists such as Jamaican doctor and leader of the League of Coloured Peoples (LCP), Harold Moody went to protest British imperial policy

Site of the train station in Central London where Ghanaian radical Nana Joseph Emmanuel Appiah and Trinidadian activist Padmore met future president of Ghana, Kwame Nkrumah, upon his arrival in the City in 1945. The three immediately proceeded to a railway union meeting nearby.
Site where Harold Moody, Peter Blackman and Una Marson testified before the Moyne Commission before its departure to investigate conditions in the British Caribbean

Site where Titilola Folarin, a Nigerian involved in the West African Students Union (WASU), recounted that shops in Regent Street started to sell 'ladies' hats, almost in exactly the same style and shape' as she and her associates had worn when shopping there on previous occasions.
Site of the headquarters of the Royal Empire Society where activists like Jamaican journalist and broadcaster Una Marson attended talks during the 1930s and 40s.
Site of students' accomodation for 'colonial students' studying at the London School of Economics.
Site of Bedford College in Regent's Park where Jamaican journalist and broadcaster Una Marson had a small temporary office before it was hit by a German bomb.

Site of a London intersection where Trinidadian Marxist C.L.R. James addressed a crowd at an International African Friends of Ethiopia (IAFE) rally in August 1935. James informed the crowd that if Ethiopians lost their fight against Italy, 'we look to them to destroy their country rather than hand it over to the invader'. He added, 'Let them burn down Addis Ababa, let them poison their wells and water-holes, let them destroy every blade of vegetation'.

column2: Oak Cottage, No.27 Burghley Road, Wimbledon
column8: Site of the cottage belonging to anti-imperialist Reginald Reynolds and his wife, novelist Ethel Mannin, where Trinidadian activist George Padmore became a frequent visitor, debating politics and going to the theatre.

Site where African American Colonel Please B. Rogers of the London Base Command commented in 1943 that 'negro British nationals are rightly incensed' by US army discrimination and had been 'cursed, made to get off the sidewalk, leave eating places and... separared form their white wives'.

Site where two white US Marines attacked a West Indian civilian and threatened him with a knife. A storm of protest soon followed and the incident was drawn to the attention of the Colonial, Foreign and Home Offices.

Site of Battersea Town Hall, where a conference in 1937 called for an alliance of 'colonial' and British workers to oppose German imperialism. Leading left-wing academics G.D.H. Cole and Harold Laski were in attendence.
Site of the 'Soviet Life Exhibition' in August 1941, which Trinidadian activist Padmore attended. Padmore brought along white activist Arthur Clegg and showed him around enthusiastically.

Site of the temporary residence of African American reporter Ollie Stewart. As well as describing various aspects of life in Britain for African American GIs, Stewart used his column to solicit letters from 'American girls' for RAF member Vincent Bunting to be sent to this address.
Site of the U.S. Embassy, where African American journalist Ollie Stewart reported on a visit from Eleanor Roosevelt in 1942.
Site where Elizabeth Phillips, the first African American women to be sent to report on the war, was hospitalized for a short period in late 1944 and early 1945.
Site of a theatre in London where a 1935 gathering featured 'famous Negro artists'. The gathering was patronised by Liberal Lord Noel-Buxton

Site where a New Year's dance was held at the end of 1935, to support the Scottsboro Boys, a group of black youths wrongly imprisoned for raping two white women on a train in Alabama in 1931. Their case garnered international attention through the decade and allowed far-left groups including the Communist Party to try and harness black support by promoting their support for racial justice.

Site of a house where Indian radicals discussed anti-imperial ideals freely. Trinidadian activist George Padmore also visited on occassion, evidencing a crossover between pan-African and Asian anti-imperial political activism.

Site of the Quaker headquarters, where a number of black conferences took place, including the anti-imperial 'Worker's Exhibition' which was transfered from Glasgow to London for an eight day exhibition in January 1939. Amoung the participants were French Trotskyist sympathizer and anarcho-syndicalist Daniel Guerin, who spoke of the situation in France, and Trinidadian Marxist C.L.R. James' associate, Athur Ballard, from the Centre against Imperialism.

Site of a Methodist meeting place where an interracial group gathered in October 1936. Famous Jamaican black nationalist Marcus Garvey, who had recently arrived in the city, reported back on the meeting to British abolitionist Lady Kathleen Simon.

Site of the headquarters of the League of Coloured Peoples (LCP) after 1944, where long-time British abolitionist Viscountess Kathleen Simon (whose husband was Lord Chancellor at the time) led the opening ceremony.

Site of a world-renowned children's hospital where Princess Tsehai of Ethiopia trained as a student nurse. Whilst working here, the Princess became good friends with British abolitionist Lady Kathleen Simon who was full of admiration for her.

Site of the New Burlington Galleries, where American singer and activist Paul Robeson gave a 1938 performance in support of German refugees. Robeson's performance took place concurrently with an exhibition on modern German art.

column3: Strangers' Home for Asiatics, Africans and South Sea Islanders
column8: Site of a house where Asian and African seamen could stay during their spells in London. Upon the closure of the house in 1937, plans were made to develop a home for the seamen 'of Asia and Africa', but these fell through.

Site of a nightclub where Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader Edmundo Ros' orchestra played during the war. The Coconut Grove allowed employees and their immediate relations shelter during the Blitz, until they discovered that a 'corner was flea-ridden, so they had to clear everybody out and clear it up'.

Site of a nightclub where Trinidadian vocalist and bandleader Edmundo Ros' orchestra played during the war. Members included Winston Churchill and Charles de Gaulle and the club was also where Princess Elizabeth danced for the first time in public.

column3: Tilbury Shelter, Commercial Road Goods Depot
column8: Site of an overcrowded 'hellhole,' where 16,000 Londoners, including black people, took shelter during bombing raids in 1940. 'Every race and colour in the world were represented there,' wrote a visitor, 'whites, negroes, Chinese, hindus, Polynesians, levantines, Eastern Europeans, Jews, gentiles, Moslems and probably sun-worshippers were all piled there in miscellaneous confusion'.

Site of the house where Guyanese jazz band leader Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson and his partner Gerald Hamilton lived together in 1940. Upon the start of the Blitz, the couple moved out to a cottage in Bray, Berkshire.
Site of the upmarket restaurant where Guyanese jazz band leader Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson dined on the evening he died. Johnson rushed his dinner at the restaurant, arriving at the Cafe de Paris early.
Site of a branch of the Universal Negro Improvement Association in Canning Town

column3: Improved Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks of the World
column8: Site of a branch of the Elks fraternity in Canning Town.
Site of what Peter Abraham's referred to as 'a hot little club, crammed with pretty girls and more black men than I had seen in London up to then.'

Site of the War Office, the centre of the British military effort in the Second World War, where Kenyan activist and future religious leader Bildad Kaggia worked. The War Office included a department set up to deal with the rehabilitation of captured African soldiers.
Site of the medical practice of Grenadian surgeon David Pitt, opened in 1947. The Gower Street surgery became a focus for expatriate West Indians.

Site of the headquarters of the Victoria League, a voluntary society providing facilities for members of the Empire in London. Its facilities for students were far more extensive than those of the Royal Empire Society or the Overseas League.

Site of the International Language Club, which helped black students to find lodgings in London. The club opened in 1937, and was run privately by Terence Driscoll. In 1946, Driscoll claimed that he had helped 6000 students.
Site of Student Movement House, a residence for students in the Empire, which moved here on Gower Street from its previous location in Russell Square 1938.

Site of the 'British Empire Communist Parties Conference' in 1947, which Ghanaian activist and Commuist Party member Desmond Buckle attended. In his report to the 1947 conference Buckle linked the struggle against colonialism with the struggle against capitalism, arguing how: 'in the wartime mobilization of manpower and material resources of the colonies in East and West Africa and in the Caribbean, monopoly capital had been given scope to consolidate its strangle-hold and to extend its sphere of influence. . .  It would be of no benefit for a colony to acquire nominal independence which left the monopolies intact'; Also site of the 'World Federation Democratic Youth' conference in November 1945.
Site of the first West Indian Student's Conference in 1945. At this Conference, the West Indian Student's Union (WISU) was formed.
Site of the Russian Dancing Academy, where Jamaican choreographer Berto Pasuka studied during the Second World War.

Site of the American Red Cross Club in London during the Second World War, where African American volunteers worked. As its director noted: 'We were confronted with the task of turning a badly blitzed structure into a club edifice that would house 300 soldiers overnight and afford daily cafeteria and recreational facilities. All these things were to progress in direct proportion to the working relationship we could build up with the British public and their established agencies... The Red Cross Club which loomed at the outset in some American minds as an impossibility is now one of the best working organizations in Great Britain'.
Site where twenty 'colonial' seamen met in 1935 to oppose the discriminatory British Shipping Subsidy Act and created the Coloured Seamen's Association (CSA).
Site of the Freedom Press Rooms, where Barbadian sailor Chris Braitwaite (Jones) spoke about 'Colonial Blacks on the Move' in 1943.
Site of LCP conferences: see The Keys July 1933 for leads, and others for details
Site of the Bouillabaisse Club, where black and white servicemen danced with women side-by-side during the war.
Site where a 'private and unofficial' hostel stood for visiting colonial students for over two decades before closing in 1936.

Site of the White City Stadium in West London where New Jersey Sergeant Christopher Lipscombe beat white opponents to win a serivce track event. The caption below a picture of Lipscombe in the Baltimore Afro-American read: 'Sergeant Christopher Lipscombe of Plainsfield, NJ, duplicates the feats of colored GIs who have been winning in track and field championships in service meets in every section of the world'.

Site of the American Liberty Club, where African American soldiers relaxed and socialized during their free time. The Liberty Club was seen as a 'base' from where GIs could 'proceed on' to other places via train.

Site of the King's Hall, where a protest called by the Swaraj Freedom House against the use of Indian Troops in southeast Asia was attended by American pan-Africanist leader W.E.B. DuBois and Trinidadian activist George Padmore.
Site of the Narod Press, which printed various radical publications during the 1930s including the Trotskeyist journal 'Fight!' which was edited by Trinidadian Marxist C.L.R. James.
Site of the Metropolitan Police Headquarters and location of the Criminial Investigation Department (CID) school, where African American corporal Cleather H. Hathcock attended.
Site of the residence of E. Ita Ekpenyon, a Nigerian air raid warden who worked during the height of the Blitz.

Site of public lectures to train new air raid wardens including Nigerian E. Ita Ekpenyon. Courses were offered which extended over a period of several weeks and covered a number of subjects, including general organisation of civil defence, incendiary bombs control, protection against high-explosive bombs, war gases and personal protection against gas, and elements of first aid.
Site of the temporary home of the Colonial Office Welfare Department, where black individiuals went to petition the government.
Site of the offices of the 'Welfare of Africans in Europe War Fund'.

Site of an expansion 'annex' created to deal with an overflow of black residents from the crowded Colonial Centre. The site was chosen by Colonial Office officials in September 1943 and repaired in time for the 'Christmas rush', opening December 17.

Site of a property visited by Colonial Office administrators as a possible site of expansion for the Colonial Centre. The place was turned down as there was a resident in the top floor and the Colonial Office frowned upon forced aquisitions
Site of Church Missionary House, where the Anglo-African society was founded to support black students and workers in Great Britain.

Site of the Headquarters of the European Theatre of Operations of the U.S. army, where leader of League of Coloured Peoples (LCP), Harold Moody, was invited to discuss 'the Leagueâs proposal to do something to help the Negro American troops'.

column2: The Honourable Society of the Inner Temple
column8: Site of the Inner Temple, one of the four Inns of Court in London, where black students studied to become lawyers.
Site of the Prince of Wales Hospital, where Kofoworola Abeni Pratt, who was later to become one of the first black NHS nurses, worked during the Second World War.
Site of Walton Hospital, where black nurse Dolly Morgan worked during the Second World War.
Site of an assisted living home for pensioners, where black nurse Barbara Nicols worked during the Second World War.
Site of Len Bradbrook's house, a black Londoner who worked nearby at a local cinema and as an ARP warden during the war.
Site of the home of Bertram Hicks, a Trinidadian entrepreneur who owned the New Florida nightclub nearby.
Site of the home of Nigerian pianist Fela Sowande who appeared regularly on the west end stage and in various BBC recordings during the war.
Site of the home of Jamaican musician Leslie 'Jiver' Hutchinson
Site of the home of Guyanan jazz band leader and dancer Ken 'Snakehips' Johnson, killed when a bomb hit the Cafe de Paris while he was playing in March 1941.
Site of the home of Jamaican musician Leslie 'Jiver' Hutchinson
Site of the home of black British guitarrist Joe Deniz. Deniz was originally from Cardiff and, along with brother Frank, featured in several jazz bands in the West End in the late 1930s and 40s.
Site of the home of virtuoso Jamaican pianist Yorke de Souza
Site of the home of Trinidadian musician Wally Bowen
Site of Chansitory House, a place where the West African Review was written, published and sold. The magazine was popular among west Africans in London.
Site of Claridge's, an exclusive hotel which Colonial Office papers recorded catered to affluent black clients during the war.
Site of the Berkeley, an exclusive hotel which Colonial Office papers recorded catered to affluent black clients

Site of the Ministry of Labour during the Second World War, where a group of African workers visited in 1942 to discuss the colour bar (which official governmental policy did not condone but which operated in many areas of life in practice) with a ministry representative.
Site of the home of Jamaican saxophonist Joe Appleton
Site of Normal Correspondence College, which advertised regularly in WASU Journal.
Site of the Gaiety Theatre, where the 'Black Birds' revue appeared in 1936, featuring many black entertainers. The Theatre was heavily bombed during the war and closed in 1956.

Site of the home of Christopher Braithwaite, founder of the Coloured Seamen's Association and activist involved in the International Africa Service Bureau (IASB), and his family, in an impoverished area of East London. Braithwaite would look after his mostly white neighbourhood by cooking meals of fish and rice for residents.
Site of the home of Evelyn Dove, black Londoner, singer and actress.
Site of the home of Frank Dove, a black Londoner who fought in the First World War before becoming a barrister

Site of St. Martin-in-the-Fields, an Anglican church at the corner of Trafalgar Square where the West African Students Union (WASU) held a Thanksgiving service for its eleventh anniversary in 1936. The service involved readings, signing and pageantry.
Site of the home of Freddy Grant, a Guyanan jazz performer and calypso singer who served in the RAF in wartime.
Site of the boarding house where Barbadian Marxist scholar and poet Peter Blackman lived.
Site of the home of famous racing tipster, Ras Prince Monolulu, born Peter Carl Mackay, at the time of the 1939 Register.
Site of the home of African American jazz trombonist Ellis Jackson and his family.
Site of the home of Jamaican actor and singer Rudolph 'Rudy' Evans (Andre Dakar).
Site of the home of Adeleke Adedoyin, a disgruntled formed West African Students Union member who appealed to the Colonial Office for financial action to be taken against Ladipo Solanke.
Site of King's Cross Methodist Church, an organisaton that loaned visiting student Adeleke Adedoyin 'some pounds' to make ends meet in 1937.
Site of Manchester Square where mixed race Briton and dancer Laureen Goodare was a fire watcher during the war.
Site of the West African Student Union's (WASU) auditors, Tansley Witt & Co. Chartered Accountants.
Site of the West African Student Union's (WASU) solicitors, R. C. Bartlett & Co.
Site of the West African Student Union's (WASU) bankers, the Charing Cross Branch of Barclays.
Site of the home of Ghanaians Winifred Biney and her musician husband Joe Kwesi Biney.
Site of the home of Nigerian writer and pan-African leader Nathaniel Fadipe.
Site of the home of the St. Lucian economist and future noble prize winner W. Arthur Lewis.

Site of the home and workplace of Ethiopian domestic servant Selassie Getahum-Wolde. The house was the home of Sidney Barton, the former British Minister to Ethiopia who helped facilitate the escape of Haile Selassie following the Italian invasion.
Site of the residence of Emperor Haile Selassie and various other members of the imperial family at the time of the 1939 Register
Site of the home of Princess Tsehai, daughter of exiled Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie, who lived here while training to be a nurse.
Site of the home of Trinidadian musician Edmundo Ross.
Site of the home of black British musician Clara Deniz and her husband black British musician Frank Deniz, both of whom moved to the city from Cardiff in the 1930s.
Site of Wembley Stadium, where American boxer John Henry Lewis fought in front of a capacity crowd in November 1936.
Site of the National Sporting Club, the leading Boxing institution in England, which made African American boxer Henry Armstrong an honourary member in May 1939.
Site of the Haringey Arena, where African American boxer Lloyd Marshall, from Cleveland, Ohio, knocked out British light heavyweight champion Freddy Mills in 1947.
Site of the CafÃ© Royal, where Guyanese Rudolph Dunbar visited and was wished luck by fellow conductor Basil Cameron before Dunbar's appearance at the London Philharmonic.
Site of the Duchess Club, a popular club run by African-Americans for black GIs and WAACs. The NAACP's Crisis Magazine regarded it as an example of Jim Crow segregation exported to London.

Site of Archer Street, described by Jamaican jazz musician Coleridge Goode as 'the traditional place where the musicians met during the day, crowding the pavement, exchanging gossip and fixing up gigs'.
Site of the 'Slip In', an infamous nighclub reportedly frequented by criminals. Jamaican jazz musician Coleridge Goode performed here nightly following his shift at the nearby Panama Club.
Site of Hampstead Town Hall, where Jamaican jazz musician Coleridge Goode married Hungarian refugee Gertrude Selmeczi in January 1944.

Site of Liverpool Street Station, a railway terminal and major transport hub where a 'nervy, shiverous and uncertain' Una Marson said goodbye to her associate Amy Bailey upon the latter's return to Jamaica.
Site of Whitefield's Tabernacle, where minister Alfred Belden preached to a congregation that often included many black people. The building was destroyed by the last V-2 rocket to fall on London.
Site of the residence of Marie Douglas and her young sister Cecilia, from St. Louis. Marie acted in films and had lots of pen-pals from the United States.

Site of a famous market selling fresh seafood, which was visited by African American reporter David H. Orro in spring 1943. Orro noted how the merchants there were reduced to selling offal instead of whole fish.

Site of Marlborough Street Magistrates Court, where African American man February Jarrett - a man who reportedly bore a close resemblence to Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie - was tried following a disturbance of the peace in 1943. Jarrett, who would go on to spend March in jail for his crime, was found guilty of a 'disorderly demonstration' off of Picadilly Circus, in which he was loudly blowing a tin whistle.

Site of Frisco's club, a popular meeting point for black musicians in the 1930s. The club was owned by an African-American man known as Frisco, and was bombed in the early 1940s, forcing a relocation to Sackville Street.

Site of Frisco's club following the destruction of the original in a German bombing raid. African American reporter David H. Orro visited the new Frisco's one Sunday night in 1943, where he asked singer Fay Barton about her 'cigarette long enough to pole vault with'.

Site of King's College London, where African American poet and professor T. Thomas Fortune participated in the Annual Student's Concert in 1936. Professor Fortune - the only black person in attendance - contributed to the concert with a poetry recital.

Site of the corner of Southampton Row and Russell Square where African American reporter David H. Orro described seeing a 'robust son of the shade' - Chief Steward Philip Behagen - pass by in a smart mariner's outfit.
Site along Oxford Street where U.S. army quartermaster Julius Mason sat drunk one night, dreaming that he was back in Chicago. He was taken away by police after ten minutes of sitting.

Site of Leicester Square Tube Station, where African American journalist David H. Orro briefly spoke with 'Long' Harry Parker, programme director at the Duchess Street Club, while the latter was spending some time in the company of a blonde white woman.
Site of the Regent Street Cinema, where black journalist David H. Orro 'bumped into' Corporal O. V. Woods, who had an aunt in Chicago.
Site of the Empire Pool, where African American boxer John Henry Lewis defended his light-heavyweight title in a dramatic bout with Englishman Len Harvey.

Site of the grand residence oppostie Hyde Park where deposed Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie and his family stayed upon their arrival in London in June 1936. Selassie recalled that, ' I used the middle floors of the house as my living rooms, and had a
 study on the ground floor which looked out on a garden at the back of the house.... Spacious as it was for a family, the house was small compared with the palace they had been used to in Addis Ababa'.

Site of Queen's Hall, a performance hall in Fitzrovia where Ethiopian Princess Tsehai was honoured in front of 2,500 spectators in an appearance sponsored by the Women's Peace Crusade. Una Marson - appearing in her role as the secretary of the Ethiopian Legation - was mistaken for the Princess and given a thunderous applause when she emerged. In 1941 the Hall was bombed and completely destroyed.
Site of the 'Hopscotch Inn' a club run by charity Save the Children where young black boy George Megan was pictured drinking cocoa and performing in a play.
column40: Photograph (D 19251) from the collections of the Imperial War Museum.

column8: Site of St. Augustine's House, where a young black boy called George Megan lived with his uncle and father, both of whom were in the army.
column40: Photograph (D 19251) from the collections of the Imperial War Museum.

column8: Site of the home of Robert Broadhurst, a Liberian pan-African activist involved in the International African Service Bureau (IASB) in the late 1930s. The 1939 Register recorded his occupation as Acting Vice Consul for the Republic of Liberia
Site of the home of Babatunde O. Alakija, a Nigerian law student who lived here at the time of the 1939 Register and went on to train as a pilot during the war.
Site of the home of Nigerian air raid warden E. Ita Ekpenyon at the time of the 1939 Register.
Site of the home of Nigerian student Oladigbolu Coker who was a vice president of the West African Students Union (WASU) during the war.
Site of the home of John M. Coco-Bassey, a Nigerian law student involved with the West African Students Union (WASU) who was recorded living here at the time of the 1939 Register.
Site of the home of Nigerian law student O. Egbuna at the time of the 1939 Register. Egbuna was also involved in the West African Students Union (WASU).

Site of the home of law student James Quist-Therson and several students from the Indian subcontinent at the time of the 1939 Register. He later became a barrister and was active in the West Indian Students Union (WASU), including attending a visit by Clement Atlee to its hostel in Camden in 1942.

Site of the home of several Ghanaian law students and political activists - Emmanuel Obetsebi-Lamptey, Okai Robertson and Koi Obuadabong Larbi - at the time of the 1939 Register. Obetsebi-Lamptey was involved in the West African Students Union (WASU) and was one of the founders of the United Gold Coast Convention (UGCC) which pushed for independence after the war, while Larbi soon became chairman of the Committee for the Defence of People of African Descent.
Site of the home of Nigerian student Babington Olumuyiwa and Betty Olumuyiwa, whose occupation was listed as 'unpaid domestic duties', at the time of the 1939 Register.
Site of the home of tailor's apprentice Emanuel Afolabi Fowler at the time of the 1939 Register.
Site of the home of Edenslight Ejesha Osora, a Nigerian church minister who attended events organized by the West African Students Union (WASU) while in London.
Site of the home of Vincent A. Savage, a law student who attended events nearby at the West African Students Union (WASU).
Site of the home of James F. D. Godonu, a Nigerian who later joined the RAF. The 1939 Register recorded his occupation at the outbreak of war as a 'stage and film artiste'.

Site of the Salvation Army's International Training College, where Dorothy Purser arrived from Jamaica to train in 1941. Purser soon qualified as a nurse, was featured in a wartime broadcast by the BBC, and worked at various hospitals in the UK before moving to the USA after the war.
Site of the Salvation Army's Mothers' Hospital where Jamaican nurse Dorothy Purser worked in 1941 after being commissioned in the Salvation Army.

Site of the home of Amy Barbour-James, the daughter of Guianans John and Caroline, born in West Acton in 1906. John was involved in the League of Coloured Peoples and Amy corresponded with its founder, Jamaican doctor Harold Moody, during the war. She was also an extra in the film 'Sanders of the River' starring Paul Robeson in the mid-1930s.

Site of the home of Avril Coleridge-Taylor and Jaylen Ann Coleridge-Taylor, the daughters of mixed-race composer Samuel Coleridge-Taylor, at the time of the 1939 Register. Avril became a successful composer and conductor in her own right during the 1930s and after the war.

Site of the medical practice and residence of Jamaican doctor James Jackson Brown, where his son Gerald, Barbadian Colin Franklin and his daughter also practiced over several decades. James was a well-known figure after setting up a cricket team called the 'Africs' in the 1920s, but he was struck off the medical register in 1943 for issuing an untruthful medical exemption certificate for a patient.

Site of the practice and home of Jamaican chiropractor and 'nerve specialist' J. Acman Holland for a period in the late 1930s. Holland also practiced in New York City and Jamaica and wrote to a relative in 1938 that, 'As I am situated, I donât have to bother with coloured people at all, and not even poor white ones, as I am surrounded by the rich in one of the richest section [sic] in London'.

Site of the home of British dancer Josie Woods at the time of the 1939 Register. Woods was born in 1912 in Canning Town, the daughter of a Dominican sailor, and her theatrical career included time in the 'Eight Black Streaks', reputedly the UK's first established black dance troupe.

column3: American Red Cross Officer's Club for Women
column8: Site of the American Red Cross Officer's Club for Women on Charles Street. African American journalist Bettye Phillips reported the club 'maintains jim-crow living quarters', which constituted 'the only instance of jim-crow I found during my short stay in London'.

Site of Victoria Station, busy south London railway terminus where, amongst others, African American war correspondent Ollie Stewart passed through on his way to the front in France. His report detailed how he was carrying 'two handbags, gas mask, duffel bag, typewriter, briefcase and self'.
Site of the Cafe Society club, set up in 1942 by Jack Hamilton, a trumpeter who formerly played with Louis Armstrong. Hamilton had formerly played at the Embassy and Jig clubs which were nearby.
Site of the Old Curiosity Shop, immortalized by Charles Dickens and visited by African American soldier Senior Sgt Walter J. Forester during a sightseeing tour of the city in 1944.
Site of St. James Palace, visited by African American soldier Senior Sgt Walter J. Forester during a sightseeing tour of the city in 1944.
Site of Scotland Yard, headquarters of the Metropolitan Police, visited by African American soldier Senior Sgt Walter J. Forester during a sightseeing tour of the city in 1944.
Site of Waterloo Bridge, visited by African American soldier Senior Sgt Walter J. Forester during a sightseeing tour of the city in 1944.

Site of the Merchant Navy Club where African American sailors from the merchant navy were depicted relaxing, including dancing with white women, as part of the recording for a wartime programme entitled 'Shipmates Ashore'.
Site of a statue of Abraham Lincoln in Westminster where a mixed race group of American soldiers laid a commemorative wreath in 1943

column2: Cranbourn St, Leicester Square, West End, London
column8: Site of the Hippodrome Theatre where Jamaican-born Chick Alexander performed as part of George Black's 'Get a Load of This'.
Site of the Bow Street Magistrate's Court, visited by African American journalist David H. Orro when attending the trial of American soldier Steven Baron.

Site of a meeting where activists, led by I.T.A. Wallace Johnson, reportedly decided to form the International African Service Bureau. A report by the Metropolitan Police's Special Branch, tasked with monitoring subversive political groups, noted its purpose would be to 'collect information from contacts in the colonies and dominions, especially that related to coloured peoples' and publish this in a bulletin.
Site where the International Africa Service Bureau reportedly acquired an office in 1937 as it began to publish its 'Colonial Information Bulletin'.
Site of a hair salon in London which was visited by several African American women serving in the Red Cross.

Site of the Russell Square Tube Station, which Chicago Defender correspondent David H. Orro visited during an air raid to interview people sheltering in the station. This particular station was closely located to Orro's hotel room in London, and was used as a bomb shelter throughout the Blitz.

Site of Crown Street, centre of Canning Town's 'Draughtboard Alley' which contemporary accounts regarded as a centre of black habitation in interwar London. There had been anti-black violence in the area during the First World War, but the area retained a multiracial community of seafarers and dockworkers through to the 1930s and 1940s.
Site of the home of Joseph Cozier, originally from British Guiana, and his family at the time of the 1939 Register.

Site of a US military headquarters used by the Women's Army Auxiliary Core. Charity Adams Earley, who led the famous 6888th Central Postal District Battalion of African American personnel, recollected that while walking there to report for duty she encountered 'every conceivable kind of uniform ... worn by all races, colors, shapes, sizes, sexes and religious persuasions'.
